content.title: Basic Movement Commands
content.description: In this exercise, you'll learn how to make sprites move using Scratch's motion blocks.
content.instructions: Follow these steps to create a sprite that moves when you press arrow keys:

steps.title: Step 1: Add a sprite
steps.instruction: Choose a sprite from the library or create your own.
steps.hint: Click the 'Choose a Sprite' button at the bottom of the sprite panel.

steps.title: Step 2: Add event blocks
steps.instruction: Add four 'when key pressed' blocks from the Events category - one for each arrow key.
steps.hint: Select the Events category (yellow) and drag out the 'when key pressed' block four times. Set each to a different arrow key.

steps.title: Step 3: Add motion blocks
steps.instruction: For each key press event, add a 'move 10 steps' or 'point in direction' block.
steps.hint: For up arrow, use 'point in direction 0' followed by 'move 10 steps'. For right arrow, use 'point in direction 90' followed by 'move 10 steps', etc.

steps.title: Step 4: Test your program
steps.instruction: Click the green flag and use arrow keys to move your sprite.
steps.hint: If your sprite moves off-screen, add a 'if on edge, bounce' block from the Motion category.

checkpoints: Added a sprite to the project
Created four 'when key pressed' event blocks for arrow keys
Added appropriate motion blocks to each event
Sprite moves in the correct direction when arrow keys are pressed
content.challengeExtension: Add a 'glide' effect instead of instant movement, or make the sprite change appearance when moving in different directions.
